channel.title: forensics on Analyst
channel.description: Recent content in forensics on Analyst

item.title: GCFA
item.description: This is my GCFA study plan. I hope it will help me in organizing and prioritising the topics to learn and also in estimating the time I need to get ready.

item.title: GCFA Study Plan üóí
item.description: This is my GCFA study plan. I hope it will help me in organizing and prioritising the topics to learn and also in estimating the time I need to get ready.

item.title: File System Collection And Analysis
item.description: Logical Backup - doesn’t copy all, doesn’t copy slack, free space and deleted files. Imaging - bit-by-bit copy.

item.title: Logs Collection And Analysis
item.description: Logs Different logs might be collected depending on the case: Network hack: logs of all network devices (on the route to the hacked device), perimeter router (ISP), Firewall rules might be required.

item.title: RAM Collection And Analysis
item.description: SANS Six-Part Methodology Used to identify malicious processses: Identify rogue processes Analyze DLLs and handles Review network artifacts Look for code injection Check for any signs of a rootkit Dump suspicious process and drivers RAM Acquisition Memory is the best evidence, although the hardest to preserve.

item.title: First Response Process Overview
item.description: First responders first arrive on the scene. Not always they are digital forensic experts. But what if I get so lucky to be the first responder?

item.title: IR Playbooks
item.description: These are my ideas on IR playbooks for training. Don’t judge :) We don’t evolve if we don’t make mistakes and learn from them. And we don’t make mistakes if we do nothing. Even if I am risking to become an object of ridicule, I am posting this article. I am planning to imporve once I learn more or gain some relevant experience.

item.title: FSEvents
item.description: Intro Directory events only 10.5-10.6. File events since 10.7. Each record is assigned a name which is constucted the following way: hex(last_event_id + 1).

item.title: System Supernova üí´
item.description: One of the main things to know when performing forensic analysis is knowing what’s normal and what’s not. It would take ages to google every single pinch of this information, that’s why I have decided to make a clean install of several systems and capture their state to have an idea what’s good for each of them.

item.title: Triage
item.description: Intro Ports idetify services (usually, but not always). System ports are forensically important 0-1023. User ports 1024-49151 Private 49152-last Cheatsheets for known ports here.

item.title: Data Recovery Techniques
item.description: Below are the techniques, tools and instructions regarding data recovery from various file systems and devices. Most of the below techniques apply to HDDs only. Those that are for SDDs or other flash memory devices will be specified in the last section.

item.description: During forensic analysis it’s not too rare to run into some suspicious application. In this article I’m going to learn to reverse engineer iOS applications.

item.title: Android Artifacts
item.description: Notifications Messages https://www.magnetforensics.com/blog/android-messaging-forensics-sms-mms-and-beyond/ Logs logcat command of adb is used to get system log. It’s an equivalent to Ubuntu syslog, as far as I understand.

item.title: iOS Artifacts
item.description: About iOS logs here. Logs Syslog According to Apple docs, NSLog now doesn’t write to syslog, therefore I didn’t find a syslog.

item.title: Linux Artifacts
item.description: User Data /home/$USER - user data and configs Password hashes etc/passwd etc/shadow Notifications Configurations /etc[%SystemRoot%]/System32/config - contains separate configs for each application

item.title: Mac Artifacts
item.description: User Data /Users/%username%/ Password hashes sudo plutil -p /var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/users/<usename>.plist Account Info sudo plutil -p /private/var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/Users/<User>.plist Contains name, profile name, password hint, account image, UID

item.description: macOS From Apple’s official documentation: In some cases, the contents of a volume are sufficiently secret that it is not appropriate to log them.

item.title: Windows Hibernation
item.description: Hibernation files store the last state of RAM before “falling asleep” üí§ . These files are of a particular value when live acquisition is impossible.

item.title: BTFM
item.description: dshell # MacOSX path to directory with pyenv (example): /Users/[user_name]/.pyenv/versions/3.8.5/envs/python3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dshell/ decode -l # list decoders decode -d [decoder_name] # decoder info # who talked to whom decode -d ip [capture_file_name].

item.title: Forensic Toolkit
item.description: Here I will collect my arsenal of tools for forensic analysis. Autopsy There is a good course from Basis Technology about there own tool, of course, and I am sure there are lot’s of other tutorials out there available for free, so, this is not meant to be complete user guide.

item.title: Linux BTFM
item.description: FUC (Frequently Used Commands) uname -a # extended system information. tar cvf archive.tar folder/ # create archive.

item.title: Windows BTFM
item.description: FUC (Frequently Used Commands) User Get user’s SID: wmic useraccount where name='veronicazvereva' get sid # or whoami /user # for current user System USB Mounting USB devices on are mounted automatically, but VHD drives might need to be mounted manually.

item.title: A Study in Black
item.description: Someone has violated corporate policy by watching porn using the corp PC. Do you have the authority?

item.description: Nearly all IP (intellectual property) are recreated by a competitor. Investigate the development machine

item.title: Case 3. Yet Another Linux Investigation
item.description: Running netstat, see the weird python script with established connection to some remote host: Grab the executable: lsof -p 2082 and ps aux grep 2082.

item.title: Case 4. Compromised Apache Server
item.description: Compromised Apache Web server with drupal application used for local team. There was some unusual activity noticed between 05/10 and 08/10/19.

item.title: Case 5. Kali Linux Data Exfiltration
item.description: IP theft and Kali Linux is a suspect. Has the user exfiltrated pictures or documents?

item.title: Sample Questions
item.description: List of tools List of reg entries List of known malware and ioc Terminology List of artefacts (Win and Lin) List of attacks List of scans and their footprint (try map against different OS and log the results) Re-read those diaries, might be of help Configure laboratory (Wins I have + WinXP + Linux Hacking + Linux Kali) Install WinServer VM with AD and learn the basics (Udemy course may be + Hahacking + questions) ‚ùì Which of the following encryption methods use the RC4 technology?
